Well I had a rubik's cube once... Never could solve the dang thing.

But anyway, since we're talking rubik's cubes, I thought you might find this of interest:

[quote="Ken Silverman":38dikuyc][url=http://www.advsys.net/ken/rubix.zip:38dikuyc]RUBIX.ZIP[/url:38dikuyc] (108,661 bytes, 02/02/2005): Rubik's cube simulator. Turn by holding left mouse button, rotate view by holding right mouse button. Select from 1x1x1 up to a 32x32x32 cube, randomize, and try to solve! Unlike many Rubik's cube programs I've seen, mine renders in true perspective with super high frame rate. It also includes: support for saving&loading the game state, a timer, and authentic rotation sounds : ) This program is a great tool for learning how to solve the cube - that's how I did it! (Sorry, there is no computer solver yet.)(Win32 - Requires DirectX)[/quote:38dikuyc]
Yes, that is [i:38dikuyc]the[/i:38dikuyc] Ken Silverman. In case you don't know, he wrote the game engine for Duke Nukem 3D, which was also used in Shadow Warrior and other 3D Realms projects.
